title: UKIP leader Steve Crowther calls for 'hardball' Brexit talks | Devon Live
text:
UKIP leader Steve Crowther calls for 'hardball' Brexit talks By WMN_PGoodwin | Posted: June 23, 2017 2 COMMENTS SHARES Comments (2) 
UKIP's interim leader has called on the British negotiating team to "play hardball" in negotiations to leave the European Union. 
In an interview to mark one year since the EU referendum, Devon's Steve Crowther has urged Brexit minister David Davis to take a tough stance in Brussels talks. 
Mr Crowther, who lives near Braunton in North Devon, spoke with Devon Live after officially becoming the party's leader until a permanent successor is named in September. 
He said it was "right to play hard ball" with the EU team and suggested the Tory team look to the unusual example of the uncompromising RMT leader Bob Crow, who died in 2014. 
"Hard Brexit and soft Brexit are just shorthand terms futile terms for this futile exercise we are having among ourselves trying to work out how it's going to turn out before we have even started," he added. 
"It is absolutely right for our Government to go into these negotiations saying " we'll play hardball and walk away if we don't get what we want - its how you negotiate. 
"The late Bob Crow - a great Eurosceptic was very good at this. He would walk in to see the bosses and say 'this is what we want and if I don't get it I am out of here' 
"That's what he used to do, that's the way to negotiate. It's how you start anyway."

Mr Crowther, who became caretaker leader after party's disastrous General Election showing, insisted UKIP was here to stay. 
He denied the EU vote had completed a Kamikaze mission and said the party would continue because it "stands for something" which is not represented by mainstream parties. 
"That's why UKIP came into business, that's why we were regarded by the establishment for many years as mad and that's why we, in the end, commanded a majority of the populus for our view."
